awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Long (Tsunami) Waves in Riverine Estuaries
awd_abstract_narration:
Physics of tsunami propagation through riverine environments is not understood well enough to quantify the hazard with reasonable confidence. Unanticipated tsunami behavior in rivers can be harmful to riverine ports, marinas, bridges, and other critical infrastructure. Tsunami penetration in rivers is largely determined by the interaction among the flow components of the tsunami, river, and tide as well as by river morphology. This project utilizes analytical, laboratory experimental and numerical modeling work, designed to reveal the conditions that determine tsunami intrusion and propagation in rivers. The findings would enable accurate predictions of riverine tsunami transformation that is directly beneficial for public safety and for reducing infrastructure damage in areas along rivers. The research program emphasizes education for undergraduate and graduate students entering the fields of physical oceanography, applied mathematics and engineering. Because of the topic's appeal, the project will be effective in promoting students to further advance their education and research, thereby potentially leading them to academic careers. The laboratory experiments will yield the time evolution of complex long-wave patterns which will be packaged into visual material that could be used in classrooms from high school to college graduate levels; the material will emphasize the tight linkage between mathematics and oceanography. In addition, outcomes from laboratory experiments will yield solid benchmark cases for the validation of numerical codes for simulating tsunamis in rivers suitable for benchmark testing within the research community. 

The research is designed to advance fundamentals in tsunami mechanics through the integration of theoretical approaches, numerical simulation, and laboratory experiments, all guided by field data analyses. It will bring insight into the mechanics associated with tsunami transition into a river, thereby leading us to identify which adjustments should be made to improve numerical representation of these critical tsunami processes.  The specific questions to be addressed are: 1) how incident tsunamis transmit their energy through the river-mouth environment, 2) explaining why tsunami intrusion into a river results in a prolonged water accumulation, and 3) exploring interactions of tsunamis with river discharge. For analytical considerations, the large body of work from the tidal research community, will be utilized to determine which existing theoretical consideration for propagation of tides in rivers are applicable to tsunamis. Numerical simulations will be implemented for field-scale conditions, guided by 2011 Japan observations, to determine the physical parameters necessary to properly design the laboratory experiments. In addition, numerical experiments will be carried out in tandem with the controlled laboratory experiments to further explore the hydrodynamics associated with the tsunami transition from ocean to river. The laboratory research makes use of two different but complimentary experimental facilities: 1) a 2D flume designed to study the interaction between free surface waves, internal waves, and vertically sheared currents at the University of Southern California, and 2) a 3D wave basin designed for the high-precision study of nonlinear free surface wave transformation in the horizontal plane at Oregon State University.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many observations from the 2011 East Japan tsunami revealed that tsunami penetration was much farther inland along rivers than through overland inundation. Enhanced tsunami runup in rivers can be harmful to ports, bridges, and other critical infrastructure. In addition, unexpectedly rapid tsunami penetration in rivers may hinder the evacuation process for people to save their lives. Nonetheless, the physics of tsunami effects through riverine environment is not understood well enough to quantify the hazard with reasonable confidence. Riverine geometry and spatial scales are quite different from that of the open ocean coasts. In spite of significant modeling work in the tsunami community looking at coastal areas, very little is known about tsunami transformation in rivers. In particular, tsunami’s transition process at the river mouth is crucial to model the upriver penetration. Hence better understanding of the transition processes makes substantial improvements in tsunami inundation modeling. 

Wave-current interactions have been studied previously for periodic waves in the one-dimensional background flow field. However, tsunamis are characterized as localized waves, and are affected by the confined outflows from the river, hence the problem is three-dimensional and involves in complex shear flows. Consequently, the analytical or numerical approach is formidable, and the laboratory approach is an essential strategy. This research focused on this topic by performing controlled laboratory experiments to explore the mechanisms involved in the transition process at the river mouth.

In the present research program, we used solitary waves and an undular bore to explore fundamental mechanisms of localized transient waves: note that tsunamis are characterized as localized long waves. We examined the intrusion of solitary waves and an undular bore into a channel with outflow jet where the wavelength scales were comparable with the width of the channel. It was found that in the offshore region, the incident solitary wave propagation along the center-line of the opposing jet cannot be predicted by the flow speed there, because of the wave being influenced by the ambient wave outside of the region of the jet. This may not be the case when the current breadth is much greater than the solitary wavelength such that the interaction must be dominated by the local condition. Additionally, the spatial structure of the undular bore shows a significantly different behavior for the solitary-wave-like leading undulation and the trailing undulations. The successive undulations were weakly influenced by the ambient undulations in the flank of the jet. 

The waves intruded into the channel were amplified by diffraction of the waves reflected by the shoreline walls due to the steep water-surface slopes created near the channel mouth. For solitary waves, the amplification was greatest for the longest waves relative to the channel width. For the undular bore, the amplification was greatest for the subsequent trailing undulations that were amplified by the waves reflected from leading undulations. The three dimensional and transient processes of wave intrusion soon subsided in the channel to form transversely uniform waves propagating further upstream. In short, it was found that when the wavelength scale is comparable to the scale of the channel, the wave-current interaction and subsequent transition process into the channel result in a complex incident-reflected-diffracted pattern that transmits a uniform wave upstream with increased amplitude. This behavior is important when waves with long length scales intrude into a channel, such as tsunamis propagating into rivers.

The foregoing findings provide with the understandings of physics for how tsunamis behave in the river mouth area, which are crucial for the analyses of field observations and data of tsunamis, and more importantly, will be useful for considerations of mitigation strategies for the future tsunamis. Furthermore, the data from our carefully designed and controlled laboratory experiments should be invaluable to utilize for the validations of numerical and analytical models.
